title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Chronicles chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Chronicles Chapter 17.

questions.question: Where was David sitting when he spoke to Nathan the prophet?
options: In his house
In the temple
At the tabernacle
In the fields
questions.correctAnswer: In his house
questions.explanation: The verse states that David sat in his house when he spoke to Nathan (1 Chronicles 17:1).

questions.question: What did David say about the ark of the covenant's location?
options: It remained under curtains
It was in the temple
It was lost
It was in a house of cedar
questions.correctAnswer: It remained under curtains
questions.explanation: David said the ark of the covenant remained under curtains while he dwelt in a house of cedars (1 Chronicles 17:1).

questions.question: What was Nathan's first response to David's desire to build a house for God?
options: Do all that is in thine heart
God forbids it
Build it immediately
Wait for God's command
questions.correctAnswer: Do all that is in thine heart
questions.explanation: Nathan initially told David to do whatever was in his heart because God was with him (1 Chronicles 17:2).

questions.question: What did God tell Nathan to say to David about building a house for Him?
options: Thou shalt not build me an house to dwell in
Build me a grand temple
Build a tabernacle
Build an altar
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt not build me an house to dwell in
questions.explanation: God told Nathan to inform David that he should not build a house for God to dwell in (1 Chronicles 17:4).

questions.question: Since when had God not dwelt in a house?
options: Since the day He brought up Israel
Since the creation of the world
Since Moses' time
Since David's reign
questions.correctAnswer: Since the day He brought up Israel
questions.explanation: God had not dwelt in a house since the day He brought up Israel, but moved from tent to tent (1 Chronicles 17:5).

questions.question: What was David's occupation before God made him ruler over Israel?
options: Shepherd
Priest
Warrior
Judge
questions.correctAnswer: Shepherd
questions.explanation: God reminded David He took him from tending sheep to be ruler over Israel (1 Chronicles 17:7).

questions.question: What did God say He would do for David's enemies?
options: Cut them off
Make peace with them
Ignore them
Allies with them
questions.correctAnswer: Cut them off
questions.explanation: God said He had cut off all David's enemies before him (1 Chronicles 17:8).

questions.question: What did God promise to build for David?
options: A house
A city
A temple
A kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: A house
questions.explanation: God promised that He would build a house for David (1 Chronicles 17:10).

questions.question: Who would build the house for God according to the promise?
options: David's son
David himself
Nathan the prophet
Moses
questions.correctAnswer: David's son
questions.explanation: God said David's seed, his son, would build the house and establish his throne forever (1 Chronicles 17:11-12).

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 17:13, how will God relate to David's son?
options: As a father to a son
As a master to a servant
As a friend to a friend
As a king to a subject
questions.correctAnswer: As a father to a son
questions.explanation: God said He would be a father to David's son, and he shall be His son (1 Chronicles 17:13).

questions.question: True or False: Nathan spoke to David according to the vision and words given by God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Nathan spoke to David according to all the words and vision given by God (1 Chronicles 17:15).

questions.question: True or False: David expressed humility before the LORD, questioning his own significance and his house.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David asked 'Who am I, O LORD God, and what is mine house,' showing humility (1 Chronicles 17:16).

questions.question: True or False: David prayed that God's name would be magnified forever and that the house of David be established before God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David prayed that God's name would be magnified forever and the house of David established (1 Chronicles 17:24).

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Chronicles 17:9: 'Also I will ordain a place for my people Israel, and will plant them, and they shall dwell in their place, and shall be moved no more; neither shall the children of wickedness ______ them any more, as at the beginning,'
options: waste
defeat
ignore
curse
questions.correctAnswer: waste
questions.explanation: The verse says 'neither shall the children of wickedness waste them any more' (1 Chronicles 17:9).

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 17:21, what did God do for the people of Israel?
options: Redeemed them and made them His own people
Left them to their own devices
Punished them for their sins
Made them wander in the desert
questions.correctAnswer: Redeemed them and made them His own people
questions.explanation: God redeemed Israel to be His own people and made His name great by driving out nations (1 Chronicles 17:21).

medium.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Chronicles Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 17 teach us about trusting God's timing and plans when facing unfulfilled desires?
options: God may delay blessings but fulfills His promises in His perfect time
We should demand immediate answers from God
God does not care about our desires
We must achieve our desires through our own efforts
questions.correctAnswer: God may delay blessings but fulfills His promises in His perfect time
questions.explanation: Verses 4-14 show God telling David he will not build the temple but that God will establish David's house and kingdom forever, demonstrating God's sovereign timing and faithful fulfillment of promises.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels inadequate for the tasks God has given them. Based on David's prayer in 1 Chronicles 17, what encouragement can you share?
options: God chooses and uses ordinary people and blesses them according to His grace
Only perfect people can serve God
We must be self-reliant to serve God well
Feeling inadequate means we should stop serving
questions.correctAnswer: God chooses and uses ordinary people and blesses them according to His grace
questions.explanation: David acknowledges his lowliness but rejoices in God's exaltation and mercy (verses 16-18, 26-27), showing God’s grace empowers even the humble.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 17 show the importance of prayer and personal devotion in leadership?
options: David prayed earnestly to God after receiving God's message through Nathan
David ignored God's instructions
Prayer is unnecessary for leaders
Leaders should rely only on advice from others
questions.correctAnswer: David prayed earnestly to God after receiving God's message through Nathan
questions.explanation: After Nathan's message, David responds with heartfelt prayer and praise (verses 16-27), illustrating the need for leaders to seek God intimately.

questions.question: What does 1 Chronicles 17 teach about God's faithfulness in fulfilling promises to His people?
options: God promises to establish David's house and kingdom forever
God forgets His promises over time
Promises from God are conditional on human perfection
God’s promises are symbolic only
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to establish David's house and kingdom forever
questions.explanation: Verses 11-14 emphasize God's covenantal promise to raise David's descendants and establish an everlasting throne, showing His faithfulness.

questions.question: How can 1 Chronicles 17 inspire believers to maintain humility and gratitude in their walk with God?
options: David humbly acknowledges his smallness before God's greatness and expresses gratitude
David boasts about his achievements
Believers should focus on their own strength
Gratitude is optional in faith
questions.correctAnswer: David humbly acknowledges his smallness before God's greatness and expresses gratitude
questions.explanation: David’s prayer in verses 16-18 shows humble recognition of God's blessings and mercy, modeling gratitude and humility.

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 17, how should believers respond when God makes great promises about their future?
options: With prayer, trust, and a heart committed to God
With doubt and skepticism
By relying on their own abilities alone
By ignoring the promises
questions.correctAnswer: With prayer, trust, and a heart committed to God
questions.explanation: David responds to God’s promise by praying and committing his heart (verses 25-27), showing faithful response requires prayer and trust.

questions.question: What lesson about obedience can we learn from Nathan's initial response to David in 1 Chronicles 17?
options: Obedience to God's word is essential even if initial advice seems supportive
We can act without consulting God
We should follow our own desires first
Prophets always agree with kings
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's word is essential even if initial advice seems supportive
questions.explanation: Nathan first supports David’s desire (verse 2) but then follows God’s word to correct him (verses 3-4), teaching obedience to God’s revelation.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Chronicles 17, David built the house (temple) for the LORD himself.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: God explicitly tells David he will not build the house, but rather his son will build it (verse 4 and 12).

questions.question: True or False: 1 Chronicles 17 teaches that God’s mercy is taken away from those who sin after the first generation.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 13 states God will not take away mercy from David’s descendant as He did from Saul, showing enduring mercy is promised.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 1 Chronicles 17:9, God promises to ___ His people Israel so they shall dwell in their place and be secure.
options: plant
remove
punish
ignore
questions.correctAnswer: plant
questions.explanation: Verse 9 uses the word 'plant' to describe how God will establish Israel securely in their land.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 17 encourage believers to persevere through trials and opposition?
options: God promises to cut off enemies and protect His people
Believers should give up when faced with opposition
Trials mean God has abandoned them
Only human strength can overcome enemies
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to cut off enemies and protect His people
questions.explanation: Verses 8-10 show God’s promise to remove David’s enemies and protect Israel, encouraging perseverance by trusting in God’s protection.

questions.question: What does 1 Chronicles 17 teach about God's role in the establishment of family legacy and kingdom?
options: God establishes the kingdom and throne through His chosen descendants
Family legacy depends solely on human effort
Kingdoms are temporary and unimportant to God
God does not involve Himself in family matters
questions.correctAnswer: God establishes the kingdom and throne through His chosen descendants
questions.explanation: Verses 11-14 emphasize God’s promise to raise a descendant of David to establish an everlasting throne, showing divine involvement in family legacy.

questions.question: How can 1 Chronicles 17 guide believers in practicing contentment and humility when God’s plans differ from their own?
options: Accept God’s will with humble gratitude, trusting His greater plan
Reject God’s plan if it differs from personal desires
Complain about God’s decisions
Try to force God’s plan to match personal wishes
questions.correctAnswer: Accept God’s will with humble gratitude, trusting His greater plan
questions.explanation: David accepts God’s decision not to build the house himself and praises God’s plan (verses 4, 16-18), modeling humility and contentment.

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 17, what is the significance of God calling David "my servant"?
options: It indicates a special covenant relationship and divine appointment
It means David is a servant with no authority
It is a title given to all kings
It shows David is inferior to all other kings
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates a special covenant relationship and divine appointment
questions.explanation: God repeatedly calls David "my servant" (verses 4, 7, 15) to emphasize David’s chosen status and covenant role.

questions.question: How does David’s prayer in 1 Chronicles 17 model the biblical virtue of worship and praise?
options: David exalts God’s uniqueness and mercy and acknowledges His greatness
David focuses only on his own needs
David ignores God’s attributes
David prays without recognizing God’s power
questions.correctAnswer: David exalts God’s uniqueness and mercy and acknowledges His greatness
questions.explanation: Verses 20-22 show David praising God as unique and mighty, demonstrating worship and praise as essential spiritual disciplines.

hard.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Chronicles Chapter 17.

questions.question: What reason does God give Nathan for why David shall not build a house for the LORD to dwell in?
options: God has never dwelt in a house since bringing Israel up
David is not worthy to build the house
The ark of the covenant must remain under curtains
The temple will be built by Solomon instead
questions.correctAnswer: God has never dwelt in a house since bringing Israel up
questions.explanation: God explains through Nathan that He has not dwelt in a house since bringing Israel out, but moved from tent to tent (1 Chronicles 17:5).

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 17, from what humble beginnings did God take David to make him ruler over Israel?
options: From following the sheep at the sheepcote
From tending vines in the vineyard
From being a servant in Saul’s house
From the city of Bethlehem
questions.correctAnswer: From following the sheep at the sheepcote
questions.explanation: God says He took David from following the sheep at the sheepcote to be ruler over Israel (1 Chronicles 17:7), emphasizing David’s humble origins.

questions.question: What promise does God make about David’s descendants in this chapter?
options: One of David’s sons will build the LORD’s house and establish an everlasting throne
David’s descendants will be kings only if they remain in exile
David’s seed will be scattered among the nations
David’s kingdom will last only as long as he lives
questions.correctAnswer: One of David’s sons will build the LORD’s house and establish an everlasting throne
questions.explanation: God promises that David’s son will build the house and that his throne will be established forever (1 Chronicles 17:11-12).

questions.question: Which phrase in 1 Chronicles 17 emphasizes the special father-son relationship God will have with David’s descendant?
options: "I will be his father, and he shall be my son"
"I will bless him as I blessed Abraham"
"He shall reign as king forever"
"I will make him a great nation"
questions.correctAnswer: "I will be his father, and he shall be my son"
questions.explanation: God declares a unique father-son covenant relationship with David’s descendant in 1 Chronicles 17:13.

questions.question: How does David respond to God’s promises given through Nathan?
options: With humility and praise, questioning his worthiness
With immediate plans to build a temple
By asking for military victory
With silence and awe
questions.correctAnswer: With humility and praise, questioning his worthiness
questions.explanation: David acknowledges God's greatness and wonders who he is that God has brought him so far (1 Chronicles 17:16-17).

questions.question: What cultural or historical significance is implied by God stating He has moved from "tent to tent" rather than dwelling in a house?
options: It reflects Israel's nomadic past and God’s presence with His people in the tabernacle
It indicates that God was not concerned with physical structures
It suggests God rejected all attempts at temple-building
It shows God preferred open-air worship
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects Israel's nomadic past and God’s presence with His people in the tabernacle
questions.explanation: God’s movement from tent to tent indicates His dwelling among the Israelites’ tabernacles during their wilderness and settlement periods (1 Chronicles 17:5).

questions.question: True or False: Nathan initially encouraged David to build the temple before receiving God’s word.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Nathan first tells David to do as he wishes because God is with him (1 Chronicles 17:2), but later receives God’s word that David shall not build the house (1 Chronicles 17:3-4).

questions.question: What literary device is prominent in the passage describing God's promises to David and his descendants (verses 7-14)?
options: Chiasm, highlighting God’s covenant and kingdom promises
Parable illustrating God’s judgment
Allegory of Israel’s exile
Prophetic lament about future exile
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, highlighting God’s covenant and kingdom promises
questions.explanation: The passage uses chiastic structure to emphasize God’s covenant with David, focusing on rulership, enemies defeated, and the eternal throne (1 Chronicles 17:7-14).

questions.question: Which theme in this chapter foreshadows New Testament messianic expectations?
options: The promise of an eternal throne through David’s offspring
The rejection of temple-building by David
The movement of God from tent to tent
The subduing of David’s enemies
questions.correctAnswer: The promise of an eternal throne through David’s offspring
questions.explanation: The promise that David’s descendant will have an everlasting kingdom (1 Chronicles 17:11-14) is foundational for messianic hope fulfilled in the New Testament.

questions.question: How does the request of David in verse 1 reflect the socio-religious context of ancient Israel?
options: David desires to honor God with a permanent, cedar house, reflecting royal and religious prestige
David wants to replace the ark with new religious artifacts
David is seeking to distance God from the tabernacle
David is rejecting the traditional worship practices
questions.correctAnswer: David desires to honor God with a permanent, cedar house, reflecting royal and religious prestige
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, building a cedar house symbolized royal power and honor, and David wishes to provide a worthy dwelling for God’s ark (1 Chronicles 17:1).

questions.question: Which phrase in the chapter highlights God’s faithfulness contrasted with His treatment of previous rulers?
options: "I will not take my mercy away from him, as I took it from him that was before thee"
"I will build thee an house"
"I have been with thee whithersoever thou hast walked"
"I will subdue all thine enemies"
questions.correctAnswer: "I will not take my mercy away from him, as I took it from him that was before thee"
questions.explanation: This phrase contrasts God’s enduring covenant with David’s descendant with the withdrawal of mercy from previous rulers (1 Chronicles 17:13).

questions.question: How does David’s prayer in verses 16-27 reflect the theological concept of divine election?
options: David acknowledges God’s sovereign choice and expresses gratitude for being chosen
David questions why God has favored another nation
David asks God to change His promises
David demands immediate military success
questions.correctAnswer: David acknowledges God’s sovereign choice and expresses gratitude for being chosen
questions.explanation: David humbly marvels at God’s grace in choosing him and Israel, affirming God’s unique relationship with His people (1 Chronicles 17:16-27).

questions.question: Which intertextual connection is evident between 1 Chronicles 17 and 2 Samuel 7 regarding the promise to David?
options: Both recount God’s covenant with David about his descendants and kingdom
Both reject the idea of building a temple
Both focus on David’s military campaigns
Both emphasize the ark remaining under curtains
questions.correctAnswer: Both recount God’s covenant with David about his descendants and kingdom
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 17 parallels 2 Samuel 7 in detailing God’s promise of an enduring dynasty and future temple builder from David’s line.

questions.question: What does the phrase "I will ordain a place for my people Israel" (verse 9) imply in the historical context of Israel’s settlement?
options: God’s promise of a secure, settled homeland after a period of tribal confederation and conflict
God’s plan to scatter Israel among the nations
God’s intent to keep Israel nomadic forever
God’s desire to establish multiple competing kingdoms
questions.correctAnswer: God’s promise of a secure, settled homeland after a period of tribal confederation and conflict
questions.explanation: The verse reflects God’s promise to establish Israel securely in their land, ending instability and warfare common in the early monarchy period.

questions.question: Which Hebrew term best captures the meaning of "house" as used in this chapter when referring to David’s dynasty?
options: Bayit (house), signifying dynasty and temple
Mishkan (tabernacle), indicating portable sanctuary
Torah (law), denoting instruction
Shema (hear), indicating obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Bayit (house), signifying dynasty and temple
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'bayit' means house or household but also refers to a royal dynasty and temple, encompassing both a physical and familial meaning (1 Chronicles 17:10-14).

theological.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Chronicles Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was David's initial concern regarding the ark of the covenant as he sat in his house?
options: The ark remained under curtains while he dwelt in a house of cedars
The ark was lost during the battles
The ark was made of gold and needed protection
The ark was in a temple already built
questions.correctAnswer: The ark remained under curtains while he dwelt in a house of cedars
questions.explanation: David noted that although he dwelt in a cedar house, the ark of the covenant remained under curtains, indicating a contrast between his dwelling and God's presence (1 Chronicles 17:1). This illustrates the theological principle of God's holy presence not being confined to human grandeur (Exodus 25:8; 1 Kings 8:27; John 4:21; Hebrews 9:11).

questions.question: How did Nathan initially respond to David's desire to build a house for the LORD?
options: Do all that is in thine heart; for God is with thee
You must wait for God's instruction
It is forbidden to build a house for the LORD
The people must first agree
questions.correctAnswer: Do all that is in thine heart; for God is with thee
questions.explanation: Nathan encouraged David to proceed because God was with him, reflecting human initiative under perceived divine approval (1 Chronicles 17:2). However, God's sovereign will would later clarify the plan (Isaiah 55:8-9; Proverbs 3:5-6; Acts 5:29; James 4:13-15).

questions.question: What was God's command to Nathan regarding David's plan to build a house for God?
options: Thou shalt not build me an house to dwell in
Build the house immediately
Build a tent instead of a house
Wait until the temple is ready
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt not build me an house to dwell in
questions.explanation: God explicitly told Nathan to inform David that he was not to build a house for Him because God had not dwelt in a house since Israel's exodus but moved from tent to tent (1 Chronicles 17:4-5). This underscores God's transcendence and sovereignty (Exodus 25:8; Psalm 132:5-6; John 2:19-21; Acts 7:48).

questions.question: What reason did God give for not dwelling in a house since bringing up Israel?
options: God had moved from tent to tent and tabernacle to tabernacle
God preferred mountains over houses
God was displeased with Israel
God was dwelling in heaven only
questions.correctAnswer: God had moved from tent to tent and tabernacle to tabernacle
questions.explanation: God explained that since the exodus, He had not been confined to a fixed temple but moved with Israel, demonstrating His dynamic presence among His people (1 Chronicles 17:5). This reflects God's immanence and covenant relationship (Exodus 25:22; Numbers 9:15-23; Psalm 78:69; John 1:14).

questions.question: What past action of God is highlighted to David to remind him of God's sovereign guidance?
options: God took David from following sheep to be ruler over Israel
God gave David the Ten Commandments
God led David out of Egypt
God built the temple through David
questions.correctAnswer: God took David from following sheep to be ruler over Israel
questions.explanation: God reminded David that He had chosen him from humble beginnings as a shepherd to be king, highlighting divine election and providence (1 Chronicles 17:7). This is consistent with the biblical theme of God choosing the lowly to accomplish His purposes (1 Samuel 16:1-13; Psalm 78:70-72; Matthew 2:6; Hebrews 11:32).

questions.question: According to God's message, what has He done for David in terms of his enemies and reputation?
options: Cut off all enemies and made David's name like great men on earth
Allowed enemies to challenge David
Given David power but no fame
Made David a servant among nations
questions.correctAnswer: Cut off all enemies and made David's name like great men on earth
questions.explanation: God declared He had removed David's enemies and established his renown among the great men of the earth, showing divine empowerment and vindication (1 Chronicles 17:8). This illustrates God's covenant faithfulness and kingship over Israel (Psalm 18:37-50; 2 Samuel 7:9; Isaiah 55:4; Romans 8:31).

questions.question: What promise did God make regarding the place for His people Israel?
options: He will ordain a place where they shall dwell and not be moved
They will wander like before
They will live under foreign kings
Their land will be given to other nations
questions.correctAnswer: He will ordain a place where they shall dwell and not be moved
questions.explanation: God promised to establish Israel securely in their land so they would no longer be wasted by wicked people, emphasizing divine protection and covenant security (1 Chronicles 17:9). This reflects God's faithfulness to His covenant with Israel (Deuteronomy 30:1-10; Joshua 21:43-45; Psalm 125:1-2; Hebrews 13:14).

questions.question: What does God declare He will do for David after David's days expire?
options: Raise up David's seed who will build His house and establish his kingdom
Forget David and his descendants
Allow the kingdom to fall
Appoint another family to rule
questions.correctAnswer: Raise up David's seed who will build His house and establish his kingdom
questions.explanation: God promised to raise up David's offspring who will build God's house and whose throne will be established forever, pointing to the messianic covenant (1 Chronicles 17:11-12). This prophecy is foundational for Christological fulfillment (2 Samuel 7:12-16; Isaiah 9:6-7; Luke 1:32-33; Hebrews 1:8).

questions.question: How does God describe His relationship with David's offspring who will build His house?
options: I will be his father and he shall be my son
He will be a servant without mercy
I will reject him as before
He will not know God
questions.correctAnswer: I will be his father and he shall be my son
questions.explanation: God declares a father-son relationship with David's descendant, promising mercy unlike that taken from Saul, emphasizing covenantal sonship and divine favor (1 Chronicles 17:13). This reveals divine adoption and sonship themes fulfilled in Christ (Psalm 2:7; Hebrews 1:5; Romans 8:15; Galatians 4:6).

questions.question: What eternal aspect is promised about the throne of David's seed?
options: His throne shall be established forevermore
His throne will be temporary
His throne will be destroyed after a generation
His throne will be shared with others
questions.correctAnswer: His throne shall be established forevermore
questions.explanation: God promises an everlasting throne for David's descendant, pointing to the eternal kingship of the Messiah (1 Chronicles 17:14). This promise aligns with messianic hope and kingdom theology (Psalm 89:3-4; Daniel 7:14; Luke 1:33; Revelation 11:15).

questions.question: Upon receiving God's message, how did David respond in prayer?
options: With humility, marveling at God's grace and mercy
With anger for being denied building the temple
With silence and no response
With demands for immediate action
questions.correctAnswer: With humility, marveling at God's grace and mercy
questions.explanation: David's prayer reflects humility and awe at God's unmerited favor and the greatness promised to his house (1 Chronicles 17:16-21). This illustrates the biblical pattern of worshipful response to divine revelation (Psalm 8:3-4; Isaiah 6:1-5; Luke 1:46-55; Romans 11:33-36).

questions.question: Which attribute of God is prominently affirmed by David in his prayer?
options: There is none like You, and no God besides You
God is distant and unapproachable
God changes His mind frequently
God is limited to one temple
questions.correctAnswer: There is none like You, and no God besides You
questions.explanation: David acknowledges the uniqueness and exclusivity of God, affirming monotheism and God's incomparable nature (1 Chronicles 17:20). This confession resonates throughout Scripture (Deuteronomy 6:4; Isaiah 45:5; John 17:3; 1 Corinthians 8:6).

questions.question: What reason does David give for God's greatness in relation to Israel?
options: God redeemed Israel and made a name of greatness by driving out nations
Israel conquered on its own strength
God ignored Israel's plight
God favored other nations over Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God redeemed Israel and made a name of greatness by driving out nations
questions.explanation: David praises God for redeeming Israel and demonstrating His power by driving out nations, underscoring God's redemptive and sovereign acts (1 Chronicles 17:21). This is consistent with biblical themes of redemption and God's covenantal faithfulness (Exodus 6:6-7; Deuteronomy 7:1-8; Isaiah 43:1-3; Romans 11:26).

questions.question: What does David ask God to do concerning the promise made about his house?
options: Let the promise be established forever and magnify God's name
Cancel the promise
Delay the promise indefinitely
Make the promise conditional on sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Let the promise be established forever and magnify God's name
questions.explanation: David petitions God to confirm His promise eternally and to magnify His name through the establishment of David's house, highlighting the link between divine covenant and God's glory (1 Chronicles 17:23-24). This reflects the biblical principle that God's promises serve His eternal glory (Psalm 115:1; Isaiah 55:11; Romans 4:20-21; 2 Corinthians 1:20).

questions.question: Why does David say he has found it in his heart to pray to God?
options: Because God promised to build him a house
Because he was forced by the people
Because he was afraid of enemies
Because he wanted wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Because God promised to build him a house
questions.explanation: David states that God's promise to build him a house motivated him to pray, showing faith and gratitude for divine promises (1 Chronicles 17:25). This exemplifies prayer as a response to God's revealed promises (Psalm 37:4; Jeremiah 33:3; Matthew 7:7-11; Philippians 4:6).
